fields.name: Meeting: ArchGenXML/Genesis Progress
fields.description:
<a href="http://zpugdc.org/meetings/mtg54" target="_blank">http://zpugdc.org/mee...</a>

This session will discuss Rapid Application Development with the Plone
Open Source CMS. We will talk about Archetypes, ArchGenXML, and the
future with Genesis.

ArchGenXML allows you to model your application in UML and then process
the results to auto generate an installable Plone product. We will cover
enough about Archetypes to have a basic understanding of the schema that
ArchGenXML creates and how you can take things further on your own

fields.name: The Washington DC Area Python September Meetup
fields.description: This month will be a little different than usual -- instead of one speaker, we'll do a series of lightening talks and discussion topics. We're looking for between four and six more people to do 10 to 15 minute talks about something cool you're doing or that you've used (e.g., remember, Plone Get Paid, a site you've designed, high availability plone, a really useful python library, etc). Or, if you don't want to present, go ahead and propose a topic that we can discuss for a little while -- a question you've had, or maybe an idea that you'd like to hear other plone and pythonistas to toss around. It should be a good time. Shoot Matt a message if you've got something you want to present on or talk about.

fields.name: Meeting: IP Law for Programmers (Aaron Titus)
fields.description:
This presentation will cover IP law subjects including, an overview on Patent, Trademark, Trade Secret, and Copyright (including Open Source, GNU Public License, and Creative Commons). I'll spend most of my time talking about the practical implications of IP law on the employment context, and give tips on how to avoid future problems. Topics will include: When you do a side job, who owns it, and can a former employer come back to haunt you? NDAs, Non-Competes Clauses, and Consulting: Who owns it? Can you reuse your code?

Everyone should come ready to ask questions and participate.

'A Short Pinax Tutorial' by Danny Greenfeld!

Python and related open source projects for beginners!

Based on this idea from one of our members:

====

Hi, I am a Python beginner and also and avid Linux/open source enthusiast. Merging the ideas of improving my python skills and getting involved with an open source project, I would like to recommend a meetup where senior Pythoner's can give guidance or even apprentice python newbies under recommended open source projects.

I would greatly like to hear your feedback. Please let me know if you have any questions.

Thanks

Dana

jaffd@yahoo.com

====

We'll need volunteers to spend a few minutes talking about their projects and answering questions. 4-8 volunteers should do it. Please add a comment if you are interested in doing a short presentation on this subject! (15 min)

fields.name: May 2010 Meeting
fields.description:
Advanced String Formatting — Eric Smith

Advanced string formatting (str.format, described in PEP 3101) was added in Python 2.6 and 3.0 as a more powerful, flexible, and extensible alternative to the existing %-based string formatting.

This talk will discuss how to use str.format, how your own types can benefit from it, its strengths and weaknesses, how to migrate to it, and advanced topics such as implementing your own templating language.


Evolving Your Framework Under Fire — Tres Seaver

Writing frameworks is fun, which is why we have so many of them in the Python web development world. Making your shiny new framework stand up under the load of a demanding application can be painful, but can lead to substantial improvements.

fields.name: Learn and practice Python basics with this project-driven workshop!
fields.description:
UPDATE: Friday is cancelled due to the weather. We will set up a google hangout tonight to move forward. Please join if you can. If you can't, don't worry. We will work extra hard tomorrow. ;-)

...................................................................

VOLUNTEERS!

Are you an experienced Python developer interested in helping us?

Submit your info: https://bitly.com/KRBf1h

You. Are. Awesome.

...................................................................

WORKSHOP DESCRIPTION

DC Python and PyLadies DC want you to join us for a workshop for women and their friends who have no or limited programming experience. This event is welcoming and respectful of trans women. Men are welcome as guests of women who are attending (please RSVP as well).

On Friday evening you'll set up your development environment and start learning Python through a self-directed tutorial and online practice problems.

On Saturday we'll spend the morning on a lecture-based introduction to the language, taking breaks to practice concepts on bite-sized exercises. In the afternoon we'll break out into groups to practice Python through short projects on a variety of fun and practical topics.

At the end of the workshop, we will help connect with the closest Python user group so that you may continue the learning Python well beyond the workshop.

This workshop is based off of PyLadies and Openhatch.org’s Intro to Python workshops. Our goal is to provide an environment in which women can develop their programming skills with confidence.

 

Venue details

http://photos4.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/b/c/f/e/event_120228382.jpegThe event is hosted by AU School of communication and the AU Computer Science Department. We will be in room 324 in Mary Graydon Center. (Parking instructions and directions using public transit will be posted soon.)

 

Friday evening (6/1): laptop setup and first steps with Python

7 pm to 10 pm: set up your development environment and start learning Python. Things to bring: a wireless-enabled laptop that you can install stuff to and a plug for the laptop.  

Saturday (6/2): lecture and projects

9:45 am - 10 am: settle in and review Friday's material. 10 am - 12 pm: welcome and lecture-based introduction to Python with hands-on practice. 12 pm - 1 pm: lunch is sponsored by Social Code, a DC-based social advertising and intelligence agency! Yay!

1 pm - 4 pm: projects. 4 pm - 4:30 pm: wrap-up and next steps. Things to bring: the same wireless-enabled laptop from Friday.  

Saturday projects:

using the Twitter API to write parts of a Twitter client. (Slight schedule updates regarding content may occur on May 20. Times will not change.)

fields.name: Workshop: Number Crunching in Python with NumPy
fields.description:
Join Matt Davis (bio) as he leads this much awaited workshop titled, "Number Crunching in Python with NumPy". Basic familiarity with Python is expected as Matt teaches us how to be effective data manipulators using the excellent NumPy library. In addition to NumPy, Matt will also cover related tools/libraries such as IPython, SciPy, matplotlib, and Pandas.

The Computer Science department at GWU has graciously agreed to make an instructional classroom available for this workshop. The room has limited capacity so please RSVP early to reserve your spot. If your plans change, please update your reply for the benefit of everyone on the waiting list.

DC Python and Data Science DC meetup groups have teamed up to make this workshop possible. It will be an all-volunteer run event and there is no sign-up fee but we strongly urge $10 cash donations at the door to cover the cost of pizza and drinks.

fields.description:

There are quite a few project ideas to help people hone their development skills. Please visit the poll and choose which project you would be most interested in. Or, please suggest more ideas! We want to make sure that everyone has a goal, and can feel some accomplishment by the end of the day.

 

There is limited space, so if you are unable to attend, please modify your RSVP accordingly just in case the waitlist activates. See you all there!

fields.name: August 2013 Meetup
fields.description:
Speaker: Robert Dempsey

Title: Use Python to Gather Data, Convert Leads to Clients


Description: Thanks to a wealth of freely available online information, it's easier than ever to gather insights on your next potential customers, and increase your chances of converting them to clients. The challenge is that the information is everywhere - on their websites, social profiles, paid databases, and many other places. How can you get a single view of who someone is and what motivates them? The answer is automation. In this talk, I'll show you a simple method of automatically gathering online data using Python to get a consolidated view of a prospect.

fields.name: Office Hours
fields.description:
Host(s): Canvas.co (shout out to Kallie! Profuse thank-yous!)


Speaker(s): Matt Boehm: Awesome Python plug-ins for vim

Pizza/Beverage sponsor(s): Mike Waud of KitCheck


~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


This is our first in a series of Python Office Hours Meetups, which will happen monthly on the 4th Tuesday of every month. Attendance is free, and pizza and beverages will be provided as we find sponsors to do so.


We are looking for food/drink sponsors (8 to 10 pizzas and beer/soda for approx. 50 people at most) in exchange for five minutes of air time to announce your product/hiring/etc and hang out with us for the evening. Contact us for details. Only sponsors are allowed to market at these events, and even then, please keep it low-key: encourage people to come to you instead of hounding them. If you have an interesting presentation, this will be effortless.


This is a casual "geek gathering", where short & informal tech talks happen, and you can get help/advice on a project, and ask questions about anything tech related (Pythonic but not strictly Python). Anyone working with technology at any level (or anyone wanting to work with it) is welcome. Any tech question is welcome, and there is no such thing as a "dumb" question. We are ego-free and here to help.


There will be a mix of people and skills present, so feel free to bring your questions pertaining to system admin/dev ops, other languages, best practices, installation issues, etc.


We have use of a tiny conference room, and open space for questions. If you wish to give a short presentation (30 minutes or so) on a Python-related topic, please contact me off-list: aagg at comcast dot net.


Watch this announcement for upcoming scheduled talks at our office hours. 

No recruiters or hiring managers allowed. No marketing allowed whatsoever, unless you are a sponsor (in that case you have five minutes of marketing time). Developers: play "spot the recruiter" and win a prize!

Thank you,

Gloria

fields.name: Shutdown Sprint
fields.description:
If you are like many of us, you have suddenly found yourself with an unexpectedly and indefinitely great deal of free time on your hands.

For awhile, we have been discussing a redesign of the DCPython website. Now seems like a great time to build it.

Would you be interested in spending some of your free time at a Shutdown Sprint next Monday and Tuesday, the 7th and 8th, to build the new DCPython website?

Building with Django. Repo and setup instructions at https://github.com/DCPython/dcpython-django

fields.name: Data analysis in Python: a survey of pandas and scikits-learn
fields.description:
Python has been a great platform for the munging and analysis of numeric data (numpy, scipy) as well as textual data (NLTK). However, for general data analyses, there was something to be desired. The advent of pandas has enabled a much better and easier importing and handling of data, specially heterogenous data types, as well as made the munging of data faster and more efficient. 

Data modeling in Python is still not as comprehensive as in other software ecosystems, but great strides have been made towards a very good ecosystem. I'll survey two of the most useful: scikit-learn and statsmodels. 

AUTHOR INFO:

Abhijit Dasgupta is a data scientist and biostatistician in the DC metro area. He is a high-level consultant for NIH with several years experience in bioinformatics as well as over 40 peer reviewed articles. He also works with multiple local companies on their data science needs. He organizes Statistical Programming DC, a meetup dedicated to statistical programming issues in R, Python and other platforms, and sits on the board of Data Community DC, a local non-profit dedicated to creating and enhancing links between data-oriented individuals, groups and companies in the greater DC area.

(This talk was postponed from the October DCPython meeting.)

fields.name: March 2014 Meetup
fields.description: Stephen Pimentel will present on using Python with FoundationDB. FoundationDB is a distributed, ordered key-value store with true ACID transactions. It has a cool Python binding that makes it easy to build rich data models for applications. This talk will use an iPython Notebook to show how to build an object store, load a dataset, and query the object store from within the Notebook.

fields.name: April 2014 Meetup - Matt Boehm and Python debuggers
fields.description: Matt Boehm will be joining us to look at the world of Python debuggers.  He'll start looking at pdb, the standard python interactive debugger.  Then he'll discuss wdb, a web debugger (for WSGI, Django, Flask, etc., pypi.python.org/pypi/wdb) that uses websockets and is based on Tornado. Finally, he may take a look at bdb, the debugger framework included in the standard library.

fields.name: June 2014 Meetup - Lewis Berman: Python w/C & Matt Makai Full Stack Python
fields.description:
Lewis Berman - Integrating Python and C

It is sometimes desirable for a Python program to call code written in C or C++, mainly for efficiency or integration with legacy API's. This talk explains how Python-C integration is accomplished. An example will be presented in which a Trie data structure coded in C is repeatedly called as characters are typed into a Python program.


Matt Makai - Full Stack Python

This talk is a high level overview for developers new to Python web development and need to understand how various web stack layers fit together. The content is based on information from the open source guide Full Stack Python. This DC Python version is a preview of the talk that will be delivered at EuroPython 2014 in Berlin.

We'll cover what web developers need to know about virtual servers, web servers, and WSGI servers, what web frameworks provide, the important parts of a web application to monitor, how to handle static files and conclude with resources to learn more about each layer of the Python web stack.

DC Python Hackpad

fields.name: Office Hours
fields.description:
This a series of Python Office Hours Meetups, which will happen monthly on the 4th Tuesday of every month. Attendance is free, and food and drink will be provided when we have sponsors.


For this reason, it is mandatory that you keep your RSVP up to date. The deadline for changing your mind will be one day before the event. If you RSVP Yes and don't show, you run the risk of being banned from this event.


We are looking for food/drink sponsors in exchange for five minutes of air time to announce your product/hiring/etc. Contact us for details.


This is a casual "geek gathering", where short & informal tech talks happen, and you can get help/advice on a project, and ask questions about anything tech related (Pythonic but not strictly Python). Anyone working with technology at any level (or anyone wanting to work with it) is welcome. Any tech question is welcome, and there is no such thing as a "dumb" question. We are ego-free and here to help.


There will be a mix of people and skills present, so feel free to bring your questions pertaining to system admin/dev ops, other languages, best practices, installation issues, etc.


We have use of a tiny conference room, and open space for questions. If you wish to give a short presentation (30 minutes or so) on a Python-related topic, please contact me off-list: aagg at comcast dot net.


Watch this announcement for upcoming scheduled talks at our office hours. 

No recruiters or hiring managers allowed. No marketing allowed whatsoever, unless you are a sponsor (in that case you have five minutes of marketing time). Developers: play "spot the recruiter" and win a prize!

Thank you,

Gloria
